respondent.name: RICK THALER, DIRECTOR, TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTIONS DIVISION

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear next this morning in Case 11-10189, Trevino v. Thaler. Mr. Wolf?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose the State's position were not as you accurately have stated the Texas Court of Criminal Appeal.  It didn't say collateral review is the preferred route.  It said either way will do.  You can bring it up on direct appeal, or you can bring it up on collateral. Would you say that Martinez applies in that situation?  Or does it depend on having the -- the State highest court in the matter saying, this is the preferred way to go?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And if it didn't, if it just said, you can bring it up on direct, but we realize these limitations because the transcript won't be ready, so you can wait and bring it up on habeas. I'm just asking how far -- the rule that you would like us to adopt -- you say this is just like Martinez.  Is that where you would draw the line, that the -- the State's highest court has to say, we prefer this matter to be brought up on collateral review?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The district court, the trial court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Has the Texas -- have the Texas appellate courts ever sent a -- a claim back for an evidentiary hearing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So as far as you know, the court -- the appellate court's never done that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  Why doesPage 6 Texas afford people in your client's position a new appellate counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, I don't know that you've answered Justice Ginsburg's question, and so I'm going to take it up because it interests me. Let's assume, as she did in her hypothetical, that a State says -- doesn't have any case law like Texas does, that says, we prefer you to go thatPage 7 way, for non-record-based claims. Is the difference between that hypothetical State that says, you can do either, and the Texas situation, is that Texas, in your mind, puts up procedural impediments to using the direct appeal mechanism and so that, if the other State hasn't done that, has made the development of evidence, has provided a full opportunity for you to develop a record before the direct appeal is over with, that State wouldn't be subject to Martinez, and Texas is subject to it only because it has the procedural impediments?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How -- how do you want us to formulate the rule if we write the opinion in your favor?  If a State does not give a realistic opportunity -- a feasible means for expanding the record on direct review, then Martinez applies because it is the collateral proceeding that is the meaningful one -- and then we go through 50 States to see if that rule applies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I have the same questions that my colleagues have asked.  Could you give us, in a sentence or two, the test that you would like us to apply?  Where a State does not, like Arizona, prohibit the raising of this issue on direct appeal, Martinez, nevertheless, applies where the State does blank.  Fill in the blank.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Impracticable, in the vast majority of cases.  Now, that really would require a case-by-case determination in every other State that doesn't fall within the Martinez category, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No?Page 9

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I understand that. But -- so -- so if the State says, you have to raise this on direct appeal, but you have to comply with our time limits on direct appeal.  And they don't appoint -- you know, you don't get a new -- you don't get a new attorney on direct appeal.  It's the same attorney who represented you at trial.  So that attorney is in the position of arguing that he or she was ineffective at trial. And that would be okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You have to raise it on direct appeal or it's lost.  You can't wait until collateral -- until the collateral proceeding, and, by the way, you don't get a new attorney.  You get the same attorney that represented you at trial.  Would that bePage 10 all right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right.  So you have the same system where you get a new attorney, but you have to comply with the time limits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And then you say, well, I can't do all of this social background research that Wiggins requires within the time limits, so that's impracticable.  Is that State okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That's not okay, either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But is your point that he has to have one full and fair opportunity to make the Wiggins claim, and it doesn't matter whether it's directPage 11 or collateral?  I think you mentioned that at least one State requires you to do it on direct, but does provide for developing the record.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What are the rules other than the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals having said, in several decisions, the preferred route is collateral review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm not sure exactly what Justice Ginsburg's formulation was, but I didn't -- I don't understand why you didn't say, oh, yes, that's right, there has to be one full fair opportunity to raise the issue.  And that's what we are arguing here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then the next -- then my question is:  Does this apply just to capital cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could we in a -- oh.  So this doesn't apply just to capital cases, in your opinion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, you -- you started to answer this question, but it is something raised by many of the amici opposing your position, which is that, by adopting your position, we're essentially having to examine the 49-plus -- because we have territories that have collateral and direct review as well -- plus systems to see which apply -- to which Martinez applies and which -- to which Martinez doesn't apply. And so the question is:  How do we write this to sort of give enough guidance, so that we're not examining each of the 49 -- or 49 systems -- or maybe 48, after we've decided Martinez?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And -- and why should wePage 14 not fear that outcome?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So the reason why -- the reason why there was a movement to channel ineffective assistance of counsel claims to collateral review is that it is often -- maybe in the great majority of cases -- impracticable to adjudicate them on direct appeal.  So, under your standard, it seems to me that covers every State.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, your friend says, page 18 of his brief, that you do.  He says,Page 15 "Under Texas Rule of Appellate Procedure 21, direct appeal counsel can supplement the record with evidence developed by investigators and experts, the ones that are appointed and paid for by the State on appeal." Now, is that just wrong?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So if everything -- if everything in Texas's system were the same, but you had a year, would that flip Texas into a different category?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Is the problem -- is what makes this impracticable just the amount of time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, let me try this one more time.  You -- you seem to say, in your brief, that the Kansas procedure and the -- the Michigan procedure take those States outside of the Martinez category; is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right.  Now, as I understand the procedure in those cases, it is the following:  On direct appeal, the attorney can make a motion for a new trial based on ineffective assistance of counsel, and, if some threshold is met, the appellate court can remand the case to the trial court for a hearing on ineffective assistance. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Okay.  And that would -- in most of those cases, the attorney on direct appeal is going to be the attorney who represented the defendant at trial and is probably not going to be in a very goodPage 17 position to argue that he or she was ineffective at trial, but that would still be okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And if you don't do that, you've lost it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, if that is the system in Kansas and Michigan, then why -- why is it outside Martinez, if the point is you can't effectively present the ineffective assistance counsel when you've got the same counsel who was alleged to have been ineffective and is not going to condemn himself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Explain why the time that you have on direct appeal isn't adequate.  So you say you need -- need to investigate.  Well, some of the things, like school records, his prison records, it doesn't take a long time to get those, does it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, surely -- surely, the trial court in Texas, when it gets a new trial motion within 30 days, and the new counsel on appeal says, well, I have reason to believe -- well, we can see that there wasn't an adequate investigation of mitigating circumstances or whatever made below, and I would like the time to conduct -- you know, the psychological evaluation or to contact these witnesses, is the trial court going to say no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And because of the rather sharp disagreements in the briefs on what the actual facts are here, I looked at the brief filed by the StatePage 20 Bar of Texas in support of neither party. Can you tell me -- and that they are critical of having new counsel work simultaneously on a simultaneous timeframe concurrently with the -- with the new direct appeal counsel. Can you tell me how anything that's said in the Texas Bar briefs helps your case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Oldham?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why is it a second bite when the Texas Supreme Court -- court of criminal appeals, has said, again and again, as a general rule, defendants should not raise ineffective assistance of trial counsel on direct appeal, should raise it on collateral review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I don't -- does the statement "defendants should not raise ineffective assistance of trial counsel on direct appeal" doesn't mean what it says?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But then -- but the comment is that the record has to be done within a very short period of time, and the -- and the trial record isn't even available for -- the transcript, for some 7 months.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So the new counsel onPage 24 direct waits for 7 months, gets the transcript.  In the meantime, let's assume has made some investigation, and he said -- and he tells the appellate court, we have some very important material that we want to introduce and we need to supplement the record; please remand this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That -- that has never happened in the State of Texas in a capital case, I take it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the Fifth Circuit was wrong, the circuit that ruled in favor of Texas, but said, in the Ibarra case, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals has made it clear that State habeas petitions -- and the State habeas petition is the preferred vehicle for developing ineffective assistance claims?Page 25 Was that wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you just please --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Oldham, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Sotomayor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Let me understand what you are suggesting.  Counsel doesn't have a record.  He or she is newly appointed.  Can they go into court and say, I don't know if there is an ineffective assistance of counsel claim, but I need to protect my client and abate this hearing now, until I get the trial record, whether it takes 6 months, 7 months, or a year. What will the court do with its rule that requires counsel to provide affidavits setting forth the good-faith basis for a claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How many were given an indefinite stay until they got the trial record to setPage 26 forth the affidavits?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what do you do with the 75-day rule, which I think is absolute, which says, if the court hasn't ruled on the new trial within 75 days, the matter ends?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Some of them have the information, and some don't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The guys who do it, it's because they have the information, and so they've exhausted their claim.  But we are talking about the people who don't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That assumes you get the transcript.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, the 75 days has passed.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even beyond the 75 days?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So he can do this -- I didn't understand this.  I'm sorry. Joe Smith is convicted on day 1.  The transcript appears 9 months later.  Okay?  9 months later his new lawyer, who is supposed to proceed on appeal, reads the transcript.  He thinks, hmm, I think there was a problem with his lawyer at the trial, and I would like to raise this claim and get a new trial. And you are saying what he does is he goes back to the trial court, and he says, Judge, I just read this, it raises some factual matters; will you please give me an evidentiary hearing with the old lawyer there and me there, so we can develop this? Now, that is what -- how Texas works?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because I did not get that impression from the State Bar brief, but you are saying that is how it works?Page 29

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You go to the court of appeals, and what do you say?  You say, court of appeals, will you please direct the trial court to have an evidentiary hearing on the adequacy of trial counsel before you hear the appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that yes or no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Even if you haven't made the new trial motion within the 30 days, initially?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So you are just saying that they are all wrong about how Texas works, so I guess you -- you could refer to a case where that happened.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, in what case did that happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Cooks vs. State.  And they got the transcript, months later, and they looked back, and they said, oh, dear, there was something wrong withPage 30 the trial performance.  So we go to the Federal appeals -- the State appeals court, and we say, State appeals court, please direct an evidentiary hearing. And they directed an evidentiary hearing, and they had an evidentiary hearing before the trial judge -- really, what would have happened on State habeas?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Now, I am puzzled about what I'm supposed to do because I would have thought that the standard's fairly easy, that this individual must always have one full and fair opportunity to present his claim of inadequate assistance at trial. There are certain things that could deprive him of that.  One, his lawyer in the habeas State could be incompetent -- all these lawyers could be incompetent.  Or the State, at a certain stage, didn't give him enough proceeding.  All right? Well, what do I do, where people are disagreeing about how the State procedure works, as to whether it was full and fair?  What do I do?  What isPage 31 your suggestion? By the way, if he doesn't get the full and fair, he still has to show to the Federal habeas judge that he has a substantial claim, that that trial was not -- so what do you suggest?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right now -- but I'm saying What do you -- I would like you to sympathize with my problem.  My problem is I have seen -- I have a bunch of briefs.  And they seem to me that what you have just described is a full and fair procedure to develop all these evidentiary matters before the appeal even takes place. It exists in Texas, and, therefore, unless he could say his lawyer there was incompetent, he's out of luck.  Okay?  The other side seems to say, no, it doesn't exist in Texas.  And, now, what am I supposed toPage 32 do, since I am not an expert on Texas procedure?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I tried that once in a case involving Pennsylvania, and the result was such that I resolved never to do it again. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But -- but don't say never. All right.  So one thing we got --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That was a case in which -- that was the case in which the Court unwisely reversed a certain Third Circuit decision. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Oldham, do we have a clue, Mr. Oldham, if the information is correct, that direct appeal counsel in the county involved here gets a very limited amount of money -- gets, they said it's $1,500 fixed fee. But, if counsel who's appointed as collateral review gets $25,000, doesn't that suggest that the -- that the counsel on direct appeal isPage 33 expected to deal with trial errors and the one that gets all this $25,000 can go out and find a psychologist, a sociologist, whoever is going to give us a profile on this person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it true that it's the county that reimburses the direct appeal counsel and the State reimburses the habeas counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but you -- you say it's before, but this -- this indicates how Texas views its system.  And, as Justice Ginsburg indicates, Texas views this system as being one in which the collateral appeal -- or the collateral proceeding counsel is in the best position to raise IAC claims. That's -- that's just where it is.  And the -- the State Bar says -- agrees with the Respondent -- pardon me -- with the Petitioner on this point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, able -- able to be brought, Mr. Oldham, but, as Justice Ginsburg started off by saying, many times, the court of criminal appeals has said the preferred mechanism is to bring it onPage 35 collateral appeal. And, more to the point even, when attorneys try to bring these kinds of claims on a motion for a new trial, the typical response is to say, no, this is not the proper venue for that, go back and do it again on collateral review. So we have -- you say that there's a formal mechanism that could be used.  But it seems as though the courts and the lawyers, both, in Texas, are being told continually, don't use that formal mechanism; instead, do this on collateral review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, isn't the usual response just to dismiss it without prejudice and to say, we don't have time to deal with this, go away, come back again on collateral review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, because, mostly, the record isn't sufficient for a Wiggins claim.  So anytimePage 36 somebody brings a Wiggins claim on this 30-day window, the Court says -- you know, there's only 30 days, the record is insufficient.  Go away, do it again.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That's your one case, it seems to me.  You only have one case.  It's Armstrong. Armstrong seems to me sort of like proof as to why it is that the Texas courts don't do that generally because what they did in Armstrong was they ended up trying to adjudicate that on the merits and realizing that there was -- that the record wasn't sufficient.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you agree, Mr. Oldham,Page 37 that, if you didn't have the mechanism for a new trial, then you would form under the Martinez rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: In other words, no opportunity for factual development.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can I -- can I go back to what you are proposing, okay, and what you are saying this system stands for?  If an ineffective assistance of counsel claim is brought on direct appeal, with or without a record -- court says, we don't have a record, it throws it into collateral review, as I have seen itPage 38 do dozens of times -- are you saying, in that situation, that Martinez applies? Counsel raised it, but was told, we're not going to decide it.  Puts them into collateral review. Does Martinez apply there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, forget it -- that -- when it happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay.  So they haven't gotten a full and fair opportunity because they’ve presented their case, but Texas has said, we don't want to do it here, do it there.  You are still saying Martinez doesn't apply?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So because it can, but Texas chose not to, now there's no protection, there is no full and fair opportunity for the petitioner to have had that claim adjudicated? That's really the end result of what you'rePage 39 saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You raised it, and the State said, well, go to collateral review.  You're saying, no -- no Martinez protection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Your counsel was ineffective in habeas in that -- in State habeas, you -- you can do nothing about it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's clearly no Martinez protection.  The question you are being asked, I think, boils down to whether we should develop a new case, Martinez plus, in which -- even though there is, technically, the ability to raise it, which is all that Martinez spoke about, the mere fact that the ability to raise it is not effective enough should produce the same result that Martinez produced.Page 40 I don't think there is any -- I'm not even sure the other side claims that Martinez said what -- what he is arguing here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What happens -- imagine we have a State supreme court, and it says, okay, you could raise this claim on appeal, we don't advise it, we think -- it's so much easier to do it in State habeas. Please do it in State habeas.  It's not absolutely binding, but do it.  Okay?  That's what they are saying. Now, he raises nine of his ten ineffective assistance of counsel claims in State habeas.  And the State habeas court says, no, you are out on all nine, but he never raised the tenth. Now, we are in Federal court, and the prisoner says -- you know, that tenth claim is fabulous. And the judge says, it is substantial.  And he says, you know why it wasn't raised before?  Because my counsel was incompetent on State habeas, and they didn't raise it on appeal because that's just how people normally doPage 41 things in Texas, they don't raise it on appeal.  They wait until State habeas. Has that person had a full and fair opportunity to raise this tenth claim in the State court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They are not saying never. They are just saying it works so much better.  What they say is we appoint State habeas counsel at the same time, it's easier to develop it.  Please.  We won't say never. We'll just say hardly ever. Now, what's -- what is the -- what is your view about whether that person has had a full and fair opportunity to develop his tenth ineffective assistance claim in the State courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not even thinking about Martinez at the moment because I don't want to get into whether it is an extension or just an elaboration or just a situation covered, but they didn't think of it or just a lot of other things.Page 42 I just want to know, given Martinez, what do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is the standard you are advocating?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if, in fact, they say, yes, there is a route, never used, but once, filled with minefields, very hard when compared with the other one, there you say, it isn't Martinez, it is a totally -- it is a new thing because Martinez, after all, had no rationale.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm being sarcastic there, but I don't mean to be.  I mean, you see what I'm trying to get to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It was the nose of the camel, which is what Martinez was -- which is what thePage 43 dissent said, actually. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, the dissent said that. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: This is -- this is very amusing in a capital case. Let me ask you this question:  Is there anything in the State Bar brief that substantially helps your position?  I'm -- I'm very interested in the State Bar brief.  It's a little hard for me to parse.  It did say there is a conflict of interest in -- between the habeas counsel and the -- and the counsel on direct. And it also -- it also indicates that the habeas counsel has to file the application in the convicting court not later than 180 days after -- or not later than 45 days after the State's original brief, which seems to help the Petitioner here because the original brief in -- in the direct appeal proceeding is deemed important for the habeas counsel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Oldham, I had thought that Martinez was really an equitable rule.  It was an equitable rule about giving people an opportunity to raise a trial ineffectiveness claim. And if it's true that, although Texas has a technical possibility of doing that outside of collateral review, but, in fact, that the lawyers are told not to use that route, that the lawyers don't use that route, that, if they do use that route, the likelihood is that they will be thrown out for using that route, the question is why that -- the formal availability of a mechanism that nobody uses and that everybody is told not to use should matter with respect to the application of an equitable rule like Martinez?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Has there ever been such a case, any case in which a direct appeal counsel has been held ineffective for failing to present a Wiggins claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I asked, if there was any decisions that says, you should have raised it on appeal, appeals counsel didn't rely on the advice of the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, and, therefore, because counsel followed the advice of Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, she was ineffective?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, the -- the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, in addition to saying, as a general rule, bring it up on -- on collateral review, said -- and there's a reason.  The reason why is the undeveloped record on direct appeal would be insufficient to establish claims that must be supported by extra-record evidence. So that seems to be an expectation that extra-record evidence will be developed on collateral review, not direct appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The Respondent says that the Kansas and the Michigan procedures are sufficient to take the case -- to take the States outside of Martinez. You say your stay and abate proceeding is the same, essentially, as those procedures. His response is that Texas has used this remedy in only one situation, and that is when a defendant is deprived of counsel during the new trial window and suffers prejudice from the deprivation. Now, is that correct.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Finish your sentence.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Wolf, you have seven minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you are suggesting that if -- if an attorney is appointed within a few days or within a week, as happened here, that, in that case, there would not be that opportunity, it would be the 30 days, that's it, stop?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But what about -- what about the 75-day --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Kennedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I understood that, if the 30-day rule had been complied with, within the 75 days, you can ask the appellate court to please remand because there is some additional evidence to be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- to be determined.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what are -- what are these investigators, experts, they're available to the new appellate counsel, what -- what are they supposed to be doing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, the direct appeal attorney.  You say -- basically, you're saying there's no way they can do anything within these time limits, and, yet, the State procedure provides for investigators and experts.  It seems to me it would be odd for them to provide for people and to pay for people who can't do anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The statement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the position of the State that says Martinez is relatively new, if there is an extension of Martinez to cover this case, then at least give the Texas courts the first crack at deciding whether there was ineffective assistance of counsel, instead of having that done in the Federal court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
